question.name: 35.3.3.1 Independent Events
question.questiontext:
Independent Events

If the occurrence of one event \(A\) does not affect, nor is affected by, the occurrence of another event \(B\) then we say that \(A\) and \(B\) are independent events. Clearly, if \(A\) and \(B\) are independent then

\[\text{P}(B|A)=\text{P}(B)\qquad\text{and}\qquad \text{P}(A|B)=\text{P}(A).\] 

Then, using the formula \(\text{P}\)\((A\cap B)=\)\(\text{P}\)\((B|A)\text{P}(A)\) we have, for independent events:

Key Point

The Multiplication Law

If \(A\) and \(B\) are independent events then

\[\text{P}(A\cap B)=\text{P}(A)\times \text{P}(B)\]

In words "the probability of independent events \(A\) and \(B\) occurring is the product of the probabilities of the events occurring separately".


In the figure below two components \(a\) and \(b\) are connected in series.


Components connected in series

Define two events

  • \(A\) is the event 'component \(a\) is operating'.
  • \(B\) is the event 'component \(b\) is operating'.

Previous testing has indicated that \(\text{P}(A)=0.99,\) and \(\text{P}(B)=0.98\). The circuit functions only if \(a\) and \(b\) are both operating simultaneously. The components are assumed to be independent.

Then the probability that the circuit is operating is given by

\[\text{P}(A\cap B)=\text{P}(A) \text{P}(B)=0.99\times 0.98=0.9702.\]

Note that this probability is smaller then either \(\text{P}(A)\) or \(\text{P}(B)\).
